comments.author: adkierst@yahoo.com
comments.raw_text:
User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; U; PPC Mac OS X Mach-O; en-US; rv:1.8.0.2) Gecko/20060328 Firefox/1.5.0.2
Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; U; PPC Mac OS X Mach-O; en-US; rv:1.8.0.2) Gecko/20060328 Firefox/1.5.0.2

Firefox crashed without warning, upon firefox restart I was informed with no warning that I was now running a new version of firefox, my bookmarks were all deleted and when I rebooted the computer in an attempt to fix the issue, I found my entire mac user profile to be returned to default. For instance, my desktop, screensaver and dock are no longer functioning as I had set them too. 

Reproducible: Didn't try

Steps to Reproduce:
I can't reproduce it since my Mac user profile is now defaulted and my firefox bookmarks are now gone.

comments.creator: adkierst@yahoo.com
comments.author: adkierst@yahoo.com
comments.raw_text: I've now come to the conclusion that not only is my entire mac user profile to be returned to default, but the user preferences on every program on my computer have been returned to default. For instance, when I used Toast to burn a CD it acted as though I'd never used the program before. This is just one example of how the programs have been defaulted.
comments.text: I've now come to the conclusion that not only is my entire mac user profile to be returned to default, but the user preferences on every program on my computer have been returned to default. For instance, when I used Toast to burn a CD it acted as though I'd never used the program before. This is just one example of how the programs have been defaulted.

comments.creator: offsky@gmail.com
comments.raw_text: Since the problem affects your entire system, this is not a Firefox bug.  It sounds like your disk got corrupted (unrelated to firefox).  Try running Disk Utility.
comments.author: offsky@gmail.com
comments.text: Since the problem affects your entire system, this is not a Firefox bug.  It sounds like your disk got corrupted (unrelated to firefox).  Try running Disk Utility.
